name: How Do We Remember? The Politics and Cultures of Memory
base_name: How Do We Remember? The Politics and Cultures of Memory
long_desc: What is the relationship between an individual person and collective memories How do societies remember This course proposes an interdisciplinary approach to the relationship between memory and history. It explores various ways in which societies have mobilized their remembrances of the past for political and economic ends in the present how and whose memory began to matter in a global 20th century and how individual testimonies have highlighted the role of body, experience, trauma, and nostalgia for writing new, more inclusive and heterogenous histories. In the first part of the course, we will read excerpts from works by historians, sociologists, and anthropologists about cultural and collective memory. In the second part of the course, we will analyze how the politics of memory intermesh at a local and global scale, via a set of case studies that focus on the memory of the Shoah the Holocaust in post1945 Western and Central Europe political violence, civil war, and reconciliation in post1990 Guatemala and the role of remembrance and testimony for claims of moral retribution in the aftermaths of colonialism the Mau Mau revolt in colonial Kenya and the longterm efforts of the British government to conceal their violent repression of the anticolonial struggles. This class will follow the format of a seminar. The professor will give short lectures each week in order to introduce the readings and place them within larger debates, but the course will mainly be discussionoriented.This course fulfills Dietrich Colleges Contextual Thinking general education requirement.

custom_fields.goals: Students will 1 gain a deeper knowledge of the questions informing the interdisciplinary field of memory studies, 2 learn about key political events and processes of the 20th century that different societies across the globe have struggled to remember as well as to forget, and 3 apply key tools and concepts of critical social analysis.Students will describe and critique arguments that emerge from the class readings and lectures to evaluate the strength and resonance of the conclusions.In addition, the course will be writing intensive, which will enable students to strengthen their writing skills and build up their ability to develop persuasive and well structured arguments.
custom_fields.key_topics: What is the relationship between an individual person and collective memories? How do societies "remember"? This course proposes an interdisciplinary approach to the relationship between memory and history. It explores various ways in which societies have mobilized their remembrances of the past for political and economic ends in the present; how and whose memory began to matter in a global 20th century; and how individual testimonies have highlighted the role of body, experience, trauma, and nostalgia for writing new, more inclusive and heterogenous histories. In the first part of the course, we will read excerpts from works by historians, sociologists, and anthropologists about cultural and collective memory. In the second part of the course, we will analyze how thepolitics of memory intermesh at a local and global scale, via a set of case studies that focus on: the memory of the Shoah (the Holocaust) in post-1945 Western and Central Europe; political violence, civil war, and reconciliation in post-1990 Guatemala; and the role of remembrance and testimony for claims of moral retribution in the aftermaths of colonialism (the Mau Mau revolt in colonial Kenya and the long-term efforts of the British government to conceal their violent repression of the anticolonial struggles). This class will follow the format of a seminar. The professor will give short lectures each week in order to introduce the readings and place them within larger debates, but the course will mainly be discussion-oriented.
custom_fields.assessment_structure:

* Group presentation of a book (15%)
* Paper 1 (20%)
* Paper 2 (based on a visit to a museum) (20%)
* Paper 3: review of the book you presented in class, as part of the group presentations
(20%)
custom_fields.relevance:
This course fulfills Dietrich College's "Contextual Thinking" general education requirement.

Through written work, readings, films, and in-class discussion, we will examine the political and cultural agendas that inform how various societies remember--and what and when they choose to forget.
custom_fields.learning_resources: The resources will include articles and books chapters, one book, a few documentaries, and lectures.
